comments.commentBody: If Trump wins, will he sit up all night tweeting about women's looks? How presidential of him.

We are all making it sound like we are totally beholden to the president and political institutions.  As if they are the only ones to control our future.  This should be a wake up call to all that we have NOT taken care of our citizens as we should have and instead let them fully suffer the consequences of unbridled capitalism.   We can and must find a way to work together at a local level to make this work and find a sense of community again.
But Trump lies every time he opens his cake hole.

I don't believe it is a failed state, as much as a state the wants honesty, the letter of the law in regards to immigration, fair trade, etc.  It isn't that the majority of people that voted for Donald Trump are racist or are bad, but rather want to believe that they matter, too, not just those that sit in Washington or in the east coast elites.  Donald Trump better deliver, other wise, there will be a real disillusionment even further.  He was the wrong messenger but he touched on issues that people care about.  Hillary Clinton did not have a platform other than giving everything away free, more taxes, that is not a way to go forward, but does Donald Trump have any idea about fiscal honesty and discipline, time will tell.  The American public will all be paying attention.
It is "who," not "whom."  You voted for Trump, didn't you?

Mr. Krugman,

You're way off point. We share the same ideals. We disagree on whom pays for the implementation of those ideals and whom should bare the costs of the residue of such ideals: Macon Georgia or is it Greenwich Connecticut?
Ok stop attacking Krugman. He didn't stop y'all from voting.

America is unkown to elitists, who insult voters with racist accusations. Finance capitalism inevitably creates discontents and deplorables at the same rate as capital surpluses accumulate. Renown economists ignore this knowledge, and make poor political commentators.
I am right there with you.

I may feel better in the morning but I doubt it. Even if Ms. Clinton wins (barely) there is no prospect that she will be able to govern --- since the willingness of at least half (or more) of the country to elect as the most powerful person in the world a thin-skinned narcissist whose main qualification is arrogant ignorance will not abate in either case. Global warming will be neglected (or worse, abetted); the world economy will stagger and may well fall into the Depression we avoided in 2008. of course, many of those who gleefully voted for the nihilism that is Trumpism will be caught in the disaster, but will blame it on the rest of us. And we will all eventually be caught as well.

The feeling I am waging a losing battle against has been growing for some time: that perhaps the political philosophers of antiquity were right, that the "demos" in "democracy" is really a mob, that our experiment in self-rule has failed --- which would be just given that our Original Sin of black slavery (the parent of our endemic racism) has never been expiated.

I will probably be all right, as I am approaching 80, have enough to live in modest comfort, and will not live long enough to see the worst of it. So I ask myself....why do I care? ...and at this time have no answer.

Quite so - idiocy is in full swing.

After the recent Brexit vote, a program in Britain, featuring many who voted to leave included one gentleman who lamented that Britain used to "make things". Well, I have two opinions to voice on that issue, and they apply equally to those in a similar position in the US.

1. It is highly likely that manufacturing in the UK (and the US) will experience a resurgence.
2. The factories driving this growth will have little or no need for those poorly educated men and women, of whatever race, in the future. The majority of openings will be for those who can apply their learning to creating competitive advantage for their companies.

I have just re-iterated to a colleague of mine that the culture of entitlement really does exist, but it's not to be found primarily among young, supposedly lazy millennials; it exists in the minds of the working class in industrial countries who have for too long believed that they're owed a living because of where they were born.

Those poor white folks keep voting against their own best interests by electing Republican while taking disproportionate advantage of government programs brought to them by Democrats. They've fallen for the snake oil again. I cannot sympathize with people who are happy to support a candidate who is racist, sexist, a bully, and totally unqualified to lead this country.

As a liberal well to the left of Bernie Sanders, I think it's columns like Mr. Krugman's that fueled Mr. Trump's success. The NY Times, and the Democratic Party in general, has been very out of touch with the voters who now look very likely to make Mr. Trump our next president. But maybe we didn't try hard enough. Let's just keep insulting all those poor white folks for the next four years and hope we'll convince them to vote Democratic four years from now. As if...

I am very disappointed in my party, my candidate, and my country this evening. Actually, I've been disappointed for several years now.
Thanks for providing some comfort during this time of grieving; some solace in the sea of confusion to know I am not alone in being so appalled at what this means for our country and who we are.
If it's not yet, it soon will be...
No, Paul. America is not a failed state or society. But you are a failed prognosticator. And, predictably, a sore loser.
The big difference is if she had picked Bernie all those white voters would have steered towards Hillary Bernie.

And where was HRC's minority pick for VP? If Obama "taught" us anything, it's that minorities turn out in big numbers for minority headliners. Instead, she picked some white guy from Virginia. Nice going Hillary, you blew it!

And it is apparently those 'good old days' some 50% of the US population longs to live in.  I must say that until this horrifying year, I quite naively was unaware of the breadth and depth of sheer stupidity, hate and bigotry that is housed in a significantly large percentage of the US population.  This election is truly different and terrifying, and there is nothing to be proud about.
Should have supported Carly Fiorina or Sarah Palin.

I voted for a woman, but an ethical and honest one, Jill Stein. Again. Playing the "woman" card is now passé. Understand that many people value ethics and honesty in a candidate, man or woman, and that is a positive thing. Hillary Clinton was her own worst enemy as a candidate.
And that it relishes in seeing women humiliated by economically powerful men...
Until tonight I did not factor in the possibility that America might not want a woman to be President.

Relax, you live in Cambridge, one of the most progressive cities in the country. You'll be fine, in fact if people realized that they have to do some work to obstruct Trump's worst programs, but support some of his better ideas, like negotiation with adversaries rather than surrounding them with weapons, as Obama is doing with NATO to Russia, and with the fleet to China, along their own shore, that you can help Trump make a positive difference. You are rattled by the Clinton campaign propaganda, and Krugman's continuing with that, because he most likely lost a cushy job with Clinton, and has to stay at his lousy Princeton U. post and scribble for the Times, or less.

I'm 79, and am online right now (switching back and forth here) checking job ads in the Spanish press. I'm thinking I'm too old to live for even four years with a president as disgusting and as witless as Donald Trump.

My advice to every decent person in the U.S. is get-the-hell-out.

Thank you for your words that express my feelings. I do not where I live anymore and I am afraid as a female to walk this land I thought I cared for. Nothing has prepared me for this horrible night. I am too old to live anywhere else. I would if I could. I am so ashamed of my fellow Americans.
I always enjoy your column but this is the first time I have read it in tears.
I am frightened as well.

Anyone who thought Hillary was a good idea as the Dem candidate was betting that no-one, even Hillary, could possibly lose against Trump. Anyone who thought Trump was a good idea as the Reps candidate clearly thought that no-one, not even Trump could lose against Hillary.

Looks like the Reps were right in this instance. Hillary with all her baggage was always going to be a problematic candidate. Even back in the primaries, polling showed Sanders was a much stronger candidate in a hypothetical head-to-head match-up with Trump. Ponder that for a while, and you may get a clearer understanding of the underlying reality that has been eluding you.
But so true.
Wow...what an insulting and condescending piece of journalism.
My thoughts exactly, regardless who wins.

Couldn't have said it better myself -- except to add that the NYT, which ignored Bernie or worse, is, as it so often has been, to blame.  But Krugman et al. don't leave NY, which the rest of us can't afford, except for Davos or that econ retreat in Wyoming. Sorry, PK -- not for you, but for the rest of us.  You'll never learn.
Paul just did not understand Bernie's vision. Bernie showed these unfortunate white voters what divinity would look like. Paul took Bernie away and thesevoters were left with trump.

Paul “feel the math” Krugman spent months during the primary season scoffing at Bernie Sanders, the only candidate for the presidency who credibly espoused the egalitarianism Dr. Krugman allegedly supports and the only candidate who could have connected with the white working and middle class voters who supported Trump. Now—after shilling throughout the Democratic primary and beyond for HRC, the darling of Goldman Sachs—Dr. Krugman is astonished that the electorate chose Trump. If you’re looking for someone to blame, Dr. Krugman, be sure to start by looking in the mirror.

I think you mischaracterize what you believe to be the Trump voter, and your tone of condescension smacks of a really offensive moral self righteousness.  Most Americans truly do want every citizen to have a fair opportunity to create a good life, and every immigrant to have a shot at the American Dream.  What varies is the concept of how to best have that happen.

"Make America white again", that was the message of this election.

I am white, from a country neighboring the one of the apparent future first lady, so I guess I am ok. But I feel bad for my children. They are white, blond and have blue eyes, so actually they are probably ok too. However, the world they will grow up in will not be ok, they will be surrounded by second-class citizens of all kinds of origins and colors and will not be free any more to choose their friends irrespective of their religion and color of their skin. My daughter will grow up understanding that her little friend from school who is Muslim and of Palestinian origin is a second class citizen and undesirable as a friend now, and my son will learn this about his little friend of color, who was adopted by a white family. They will wake up tomorrow and I will tell them who won and I will answer all their questions as I am driving them to their school here in Brooklyn.

I feel bad for them, their world just completely fell apart.
Ricky Maddox - too funny!
Keith Olbermann's nephew looks beside himself on pmsnbc.  Ricky Maddow gonna cry!!!
Except that there's no such thing as "Hillary's crimes." If you believe that Hillary is a criminal, then you are what is generally regarded as a sucker.

"We are more willing to put up with Trump's comments than Hillary's crimes". You absolutely get it. Hillary and her scriptwriters ran a brilliant 1980s campaign. Once DJT gained momentum, they were incapable of going off script. Recycling Alicia Machado while DJT grew more "Presidential" by the day will go down as one of the biggest campaign blunders in history. Time to #DrainTheSwamp
Be careful what you wish for. You too will suffer. You will find out what it is you have been promoting when you abandoned morality and supported Mr. Trump.

You know it's amazing how her part in destabilizing the Middle East as well as her renewal of the Cold War was rarely discussed. At some point in the near future a map of the Middle East will be published showing the state of conflict at the end of 2008 and the present state of conflict.
Throw into this Obama's claim during the 2012 elections that he ended the war in Iraq and left it with a stable government along with his dismissal of the beginning of ISIS and, well it won't be pretty.

On this day of reckoning, Hillary will say what the lead character in the film "The Patriot" Benjamin Martin (based on the real person Francis Marion) tells his General after the loss of his children in the war of American independence;

"I have long feared that my sins would return to visit me and the cost is more than I can bear."
Rural America continues to provide your food, Mr. Krugman.  Lighten up on us.   Do you care that I live in a rural area and have a master's degree?  And have a mind of my own?   don't think so.
